Description: Mould-made amulet in glazed composition, in the shape of a one-sided right wedjat-eye; pierced lengthways for suspension; in pale turquoise glaze; added yellow and above black glaze in relief for pupil; detailing of eye and brow lightly incised; quite worn glaze; part of perforation broken away on back.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

In addition to scarabs which were mass-produced especially for export, wedjat eyes, mainly in glazed composition but also in hard stone, form the main type of amulets found at Naukratis. Amulet with universal power of protection (Germond 2005, 25), the wedjat eye, simple or multiple, is one of the most common amulet on settlements of the Late Period (Masson forthcoming). For similar types of wedjat eye found in Naukratis, see: Liverpool, World Museum 9,9,86,84.k; London, Petrie Museum UC52355, UC52395; Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H2009.3 (different colour though). Germond, P. 2005, Le monde symbolique des amulettes égyptiennes de la collection Jacques-Édouard Berger, Milan. Masson, A. forthcoming, Le quartier des prêtres sur la rive est du Lac Sacré à Karnak.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.290) (phase 3)
